Genetically-defined subgroups of 22 inhibitory interneurons are thought to play distinct roles in learning, but heterogeneity within 23 these subgroups has limited our understanding of the scope and nature of their specific 24 contributions to learning. Introduction 40 The reorganization of neural circuits during learning relies on a complex interplay between 41 excitatory and inhibitory signals in the brain, accompanying highly specific synaptic modification. 42 Various synaptic changes contributing to this interplay have been observed at the scale of 43 individual cells and whole circuits. The observed formation and elimination of dendritic spines in 44 cortical pyramidal neurons (PyNs) during learning have suggested that learning is associated 45 with changes in neuronal connectivity 1–4. At the circuit level, neuronal activity is synchronized in 46 a subpopulation of neurons, resulting in a high correlation between neuronal activity patterns 47 and learned behaviors 3,5,6. It has been understood that GABAergic inhibition plays a critical role 48 in shaping learning-dependent circuit changes. Interneurons are categorized by anatomical and 49 electrophysiological features, and their distinct functions during learning have been shown in 50 genetically-defined subtypes such as parvalbumin (PV)-, somatostatin (SOM)- and vasoactive 51 intestinal polypeptide (VIP)-expressing neurons 7–11. However, these subtypes still contain a 52 remarkable degree of heterogeneity, such that the precise role of inhibition mediated by single-53 type interneurons remains an open question. 54 The ChC (i.e., ‘axo-axonic cell’) is a bona fide GABAergic interneuron subclass with 55 respect to its distinct axonal geometry, subcellular synapse connectivity, and fast-spiking 56 electrophysiological properties 12,13. A single ChC exhibits a characteristic axonal geometry with 57 many prominent vertical branches, which contain strings of synaptic boutons exclusively aligned 58 along the AISs of neighboring PyNs. Because the AIS is the site of action potential initiation, 59 ChCs can have decisive control over spike generation in an ensemble of PyNs, thereby 60 regulating synchrony and oscillation of network activity. These functions are thought to be 61 critical for higher-order cognitive processes like working memory 14–16. In this study, using a 62 transgenic mouse line specifically engineered to target ChCs, we examined the role of ChCs in 63 sculpting cortical circuits involved in motor learning. We discovered that the ChC is essential for 64 improving the direction-tuning of targeted cells by suppressing irrelevant activity at the 65 population level. ChC shaped this sophisticated inhibitory motif among a specific set of neuron 66 types. Thus, ChCs primarily take a “select and focus” strategy rather than serve as a uniform 67 gain setter. 68
69 Results 70 Improved directional control of movement on multi-textured ball maze. 71 Previous studies have shown that ChCs increased activity during locomotion 17,18. The premotor 72 cortex (M2, anteromedial agranular cortex, homologous to supplementary motor areas in the 73 primate brain) is involved in gating sensory inputs and motor outputs for movement planning, 74 fine action control, and decision-making 19–21. To investigate the role of ChCs in controlling the 75 activity of M2 neurons during locomotion, we used a spatial navigation task that requires goal-76 directed motor control 22. Mice were trained to traverse a multi-textured ball maze with four 77 distinctive tactile surface cues and to reach a goal spot on the ball, where a water reward was 78 given (Fig. 1a, See Methods). The task required directional motor control accurately aimed to 79 the goal spot. While animals were navigating the ball maze, we recorded neuronal activity of the 80 L2/3 premotor population using Ca2+ imaging via two-photon microscopy. Mice with water-81 restriction (experimental group) showed reward-seeking behavior on the ball maze, developed a 82 preferred pathway, and generated goal-oriented locomotion with learning whereas mice ad 83 libitum water (control group) did not (Fig. 1b). The number of successfully reaching the goal 84 spot increased in the experimental group but not in the control group (Fig. 1e). Time spent in 85 the goal (rewarded) quadrant (Q1) increased with training (Fig. 1f). We further examined the 86 relationship between motor control and reward-seeking behavioral performance by analyzing 87 the parameters of motor control. To examine whether general movement parameters such as 88 speed and acceleration could be the main cause for these improvements, we compared the 89 motor control between experimental and control conditions. The movement of the control group 90 showed similar general motor parameters (e.g., speed and acceleration) to the experimental 91 group (Fig. 1c, d). Overall latency to the reward decreased with training, indicating the 92 increased effectiveness of the animals’ movements at achieving rewards (Fig. 1g). We 93 observed that mice showed increased proximity to the goal with learning, by tuning their 94 movement to the goal (Fig. 1h). The movement accuracy as the percentage of goal-aimed 95 movements increased with training (Fig. 1i), indicating that the enhanced movement direction 96 (MD) controls toward the goal spot. Mice in the experimental group showed better control in 97
turning toward the goal during navigation than the control (Fig. 1j, k). These results indicate that 98 the directional control of movement is improved with learning. 99
100 Motor learning refines direction coding through suppression of irrelevant activity. 101 To determine how neurons mediate precise motor control with learning, we examined direction 102 coding of M2 neurons at the cellular and population levels. To test whether M2 is required for 103 neuronal adaptation to control task-related motor behavior, we used an adeno-associated virus 104 (AAV)-based approach to express tetanus toxin light chain (TeTxLC), which abolishes 105 presynaptic vesicle release 23,24, in M2 excitatory neurons (Extended Data Fig. 1a). Mice 106 expressing TeTxLC in M2 excitatory neurons (CaMKII-TeTxLC mice) showed deficits in learning 107 the task (Extended Data Fig. 1e). The reward-seeking behavioral parameters did not improve 108 with training (Extended Data Fig. 1e-j), suggesting that M2 neurons play an essential role in 109 mediating the motor learning required for the task. 110 We performed two-photon Ca2+ imaging in L2/3 of M2 with a genetically encoded 111 calcium indicator, GCaMP6s while mice navigated on the ball maze (Extended Data Fig. 2a). 112 Consistent with the established role of M2 in motor planning, overall population activity in L2/3 113 correlated with locomotion (Extended Data Fig. 2b). Individual premotor neuron activities bi-114 directionally changed in a time-locked fashion at movement onset (Extended Data Fig. 2c). 115 The majority of neurons were movement-related (total 98.0%; positively correlated: 79.7 ± 3.3%; 116 negatively correlated: 18.4 ± 3.2%; and not correlated: 2.0 ± 0.4%; see Methods for 117 classification), and the proportion of movement-related neurons in the population remained 118 relatively constant throughout training sessions (Extended Data Fig. 2d). 119 We next measured direction selectivity of individual premotor neurons over training and 120 analyzed the changes. Distinct neuronal populations responded to different MDs (MDs) (Fig. 2a, 121 Extended Data Fig. 2e-g). A subset of L2/3 neurons exhibited tuning to the MD which was 122 defined as its preferred direction (PD). Its topological map was arranged in a salt-and-pepper 123 pattern in the M2 area (Extended Data Fig. 2i, j). 124 We estimated the likelihood distributions of neural tuning curves as a function of MD 125 (Fig. 2b). Premotor neurons showed the highest likelihood to fire at their PD. We defined 126 population tuning precision as the reciprocal of the variance of total neural activity given MD. 127
Tuning of premotor neurons to MD became more precise over sessions. The precision of 128 population responses increased for all MDs in the experimental group, but not in the control 129 group (Fig. 2c-d). We next estimated the probability of the cell being active as a function of the 130 distance between MD and the cell's PD. When the MD was far from the cell’s PD (distance from 131
PD > 90॰), the probability of being active decreased with learning (Fig. 2e). When the MD was 132
opposite to the cell's PD, the probability of the cell being active was significantly lower in 133 Session 7 than in Session 1 for mice in the experimental condition, but not in the control 134 condition (Fig. 2f). 135 We took a Bayesian approach to decode the MD from neural activity (See Methods). 136 We computed the posterior probability density function to provide the most likely estimate of the 137 mouse’s MD during navigation (Fig. 2g, Extended Data Fig. 3a-c). Moment-to-moment MDs 138 were decoded by the estimated MD corresponding to the maximum value of the posterior 139 probability density function. During behavior, posterior probability density functions of MD 140 sharpened over sessions in the experimental group, enhancing near the MD and waning at null 141 MDs (Fig. 2h). In contrast, posterior functions were flattened over sessions in the control group. 142 Consequently, we observed lower decoding errors in the experimental group (Fig. 2i). Similarly, 143 we tested neural coding of MD based on a population vector (PoV) as a vector sum of PDs of a 144 sparse population of active direction-tuned neurons at a given moment 25,26 (Extended Data 145 Fig. 3d). In this coding scheme, MDs were also flexibly encoded in a moment-to-moment 146 manner from the distinct sparsely distributed activity of neuronal ensembles (Extended Data 147
Fig. 3e, f). The fraction of decoded direction (PoV around 0॰) increased and that of anti-148
decoded direction (PoV around 180॰) decreased in Session 7 in the experimental group, but not 149
in the control group, indicating an increased coding accuracy associated with learning 150 (Extended Data Fig. 3g-i). We further measured angular errors between the active neuron’s 151 PD and MD to see how directional neuronal activity was accurately aligned with MD on a 152 moment-to-moment basis. Similar to the change in decoding error, the fraction of PD increased 153 and that of anti-PD decreased in Session 7 in the experimental mice, whereas the fraction of 154 anti-PD increased in Session 7 in the control mice, indicating that the fraction of irrelevant 155 activity reduced with learning (Extended Data Fig. 3j, k). To test whether the motor learning 156
mediates a direction-dependent change in network connectivity, we compared pairwise 157 correlations between neuronal pairs of diametrically opposed PDs. The pairwise correlations of 158 neuronal pairs decreased in the experimental group as a function of the difference in their PDs, 159 whereas they increased over sessions in the control group (Fig. 2j). These results suggest that 160 the observed reduction of incorrectly tuned responses shapes the direction coding of the M2 161 population. 162 163 Manipulation of parvalbumin interneurons disrupts global neural activity. 164 To determine how neuronal ensembles suppress irrelevant activity during learning, we asked 165 how interneurons might be uniquely involved. Several GABAergic interneuron subtypes have 166 been hypothesized to serve specific roles in regulating cortical functions by forming circuit motifs 167 with features like recurrence and feedforward inhibition 27. We tested the regulative role of two 168 major interneuron groups that are known to form inhibitory synapses at specific compartments 169 of excitatory PyNs and comprise 70% of all cortical interneurons 28; Specifically, PV-INs inhibit 170 perisomatic regions and SOM-INs target distal dendrites 29. We bilaterally silenced activity of 171 PV-INs or SOM-INs during behavior by expressing an inhibitory opsin, eNpHR3.0, in the M2. 172 We found that inactivation of premotor PV-INs disrupted goal-directed motor performance, but 173 inactivation of SOM-INs did not, suggesting that perisomatic inhibition mediated by PV-INs may 174 be involved in circuit motifs that guide task-related directional control of movement (Fig. 3a, 175 Extended Data Fig. 4). 176 Perisomatic inhibition from PV-INs provides powerful inhibitory control over the principal 177 neuron population 29–32. To further examine the role of PV-IN perisomatic inhibition in local 178 neuronal activity during motor control, we abolished presynaptic GABA release from PV-INs by 179 expressing Cre-dependent TeTxLC virus in PV-Cre mice (PV-TeTxLC mice) and monitored the 180 M2 neuron activity (Fig. 3b). Consistent with the notion that PV-INs are critical regulators of 181 cortical excitatory and inhibitory (E/I) balance 33,34, the abolishment of perisomatic inhibition in 182 PV-TeTxLC mice led to excessively increased overall activity of M2 neurons during movement 183 (Fig. 3c-d) 35 and hypersynchronization at movement initiation, which disrupted the propagation 184 of sequential network activity and decreased the sparseness of neural activity during 185
subsequent movements (Fig. 3e, f). Accordingly, the pairwise correlation and the proportion of 186 pairs with positive correlations were significantly higher in PV-TeTxLC mice than in PV control 187 mice (Fig. 3g-h). A significant proportion of PV-INs also showed increased activity for 188 movement initiation (Fig. 3j), suggesting that the excessive activity of M2 neurons in PV-189 TeTxLC mice may result from unmasked responses of neurons that were previously inhibited by 190 PV-INs (Fig. 3k-n). These results suggest that PV-IN perisomatic inhibition is involved in task-191 related motor control, but this manipulation also leads to global excitability changes that limits 192 the applicability of current approaches to specify mechanisms of directional motor control. 193 194 Sparse, sequential activity is preserved in ChC manipulation. 195 In our attempt to specify the underlying mechanisms of perisomatic inhibition, we targeted ChCs 196 by using the ChC-specific transgenic mouse line (Nkx2.1-2a-CreER::Ai14 as ChC control mice, 197 Nkx2.1-2a-CreER::Flex-FlpO mice as ChC-Flp mice, and Vipr2-Cre) 36. This genetic strategy 198 allowed us to selectively label ChCs, including their distinctive axonal arborizations and 199 cartridge terminals (Extended Data Fig. 5a-c). A larger proportion of ChCs were found in the 200 upper L2/3 of M2, with a smaller number present in L5 (mean soma depth ± s.e.m = 178.9 ± 201 10.7 μm from pial surface) (Extended Data Fig. 5d). We confirmed that the axonal cartridges of 202 ChCs made synapses on the AISs of neighboring neurons (Fig. 4a). To find out if ChC 203 manipulation impacts global network excitability, we abolished presynaptic inhibitory GABAergic 204 inputs to the AISs of neighboring neurons by expressing FlpO-dependent TeTxLC (AAV9-CAG-205 dfrt-TeTxLC-HA-WPRE) bilaterally in ChC-Flp mice and monitored activity of M2 neurons (Fig. 206 4b). In contrast to the hypersynchronous neuronal activity in PV-TeTxLC mice, we did not 207 observe a global change. Instead, we observed sparse, sequential activity propagation in both 208 ChC-TeTxLC and control mice during movement (Fig. 4c, d). Pairwise correlation indicated 209 local, not global, correlated activity between neuronal pairs in both groups (Fig. 4e); The 210 proportions of pairs with positive and negative correlations were similar between the two groups 211 (Fig. 4f). In contrast to PV-INs, a majority of ChCs showed increased activity during movement 212 rather than movement initiation (Fig. 4g), and ChC-TeTxLC manipulation did not evoke the 213 excessive activity of M2 neurons at movement onset shown in PV-TeTxLC mice (Fig. 4h-k). 214
These results demonstrate that ChCs have a distinct activity profile from PV-INs and that overall 215 network excitability is not globally altered by silencing the activity of ChCs. 216 217 Chemogenetic inhibition of ChCs disrupts the direction selectivity of premotor neurons. 218 The TeTxLC experiments suggest that the major role of ChCs is not control of general network 219 gain, but more target-specific control of neighboring neurons. We tested whether ChC 220 suppression would affect the direction tuning of M2 neurons during the behavioral task. We 221 bilaterally expressed FlpO-dependent chemogenetic silencer (AAV9-CAG-dfrt-hM4Di-mCherry) 222 in the M2 of ChC-Flp mice to suppress the activity of ChCs upon the application of clozapine N-223 oxide (CNO), an hM4Di agonist (Fig. 5a). We first verified the effectiveness of CNO in brain 224 slices. Whole-cell electrophysiological recordings showed that CNO application reduced the 225 activity of ChCs expressing hM4Di (Fig. 5b). After 7 days of training, we administered either 226 saline or CNO. CNO administration in the ChC-Flp:hM4Di mice significantly impaired goal-227 directed navigation performance and turning movement (Fig. 5c-f). CNO or saline injection 228 alone had no effect on behavioral performance (ChC-Flp:hM4Di mice with saline, ChC-Flp mice 229 with saline or CNO injection) (Fig. 5d). 230 To determine the role of ChC activity in the direction tuning of M2 neurons, we co-231 expressed AAV9-CAG-dfrt-hM4Di-mCherry and AAV1-hSyn-GCaMP6s into the L2/3 M2. We 232 then used chemogenetic manipulations and performed Ca2+ imaging of ChCs and their 233 neighboring neurons during the behavioral task. In line with the ex vivo results, ChC activity was 234 suppressed upon CNO administration during locomotion (Fig. 5g, h). Consequently, we 235 observed that the coactivity of M2 neurons increased upon CNO application during locomotion 236 but not during rest (Fig. 5i), consistent with recent work demonstrating the inhibitory 237 postsynaptic effects of ChCs on M2 neurons in vivo 17,31. We compared the likelihood 238 distributions of neural tuning curves as a function of MD with and without CNO administration. 239 We observed that neurons are more likely to be active at non-PDs in the CNO (ChC-silenced) 240 condition than in the saline condition (Fig. 5j), resulting in less precise population responses to 241 the MD (Fig. 5k, l). The probability of the cell being active at a certain MD increased upon CNO 242 administration (Fig. 5m). When the MD was at the opposite of the cell's PD, the probability of 243
the cell being active was higher after CNO administration than it had been in Session 7 or in the 244 saline condition (Fig. 5n). CNO application increased pairwise correlations between neuronal 245 pairs as opposed to the enhanced decorrelation between pairs seen with learning (Fig. 5o). 246 These results suggest that the suppression of ChC activity increased behaviorally irrelevant 247 neural activity, impairing the precise coding of movement. 248 249 Variability of ChC activity increases during learning. 250 To examine the activity dynamics of ChCs during learning, we expressed GCaMP6s in the L2/3 251 ChCs and recorded ChC activity while mice performed the behavioral task (Fig. 6a). Consistent 252 with previous reports 17,18, ChCs displayed increased activity during episodes of locomotion 253 (Fig. 6b), with a more synchronized pattern of activity in Session 1. In Session 7, activity 254 patterns became more diverse and desynchronous, which led to the formation of subclusters of 255 ChCs (Fig. 6c). To quantify this shift, we calculated the pairwise correlations between ChCs 256 during the behavioral task and found that the correlation decreased and ChCs formed 257 subclusters as learning progressed (Fig. 6d, e). We next examined how temporal relationships 258 between ChCs and M2 neurons change with learning. Various temporal relationships in activity 259 were shown between ChCs and neighboring M2 neurons (Fig. 6f). We calculated cell-to-cell 260 activity correlations (Pearsons’ correlation) in pairs of ChCs and M2 neurons during locomotion 261 and rest epochs and compared their distributions of correlation coefficients. In Session 1, the 262 proportion of high correlation coefficient (corr(r) > 0.6) was decreased during locomotion 263 compared to rest, reflecting the increased decorrelation. In Session 7, the overall proportions of 264 positive correlation coefficient (corr(r) > 0) and of negative coefficient (corr(r) < 0) were 265 remarkably decreased during locomotion compared to rest, indicating the enhanced 266 decorrelation in gross pairs of ChC and M2 neuron (Fig. 6g). These results suggest that ChC 267 activity becomes more heterogeneous with learning and such decorrelated temporal relationship 268 between ChCs and neighboring M2 neurons implies an increased specificity of population 269 activity control. 270 271
Abolition of ChC inhibition impairs refinement of direction coding and motor learning. 272 We asked if the abolition of ChC-mediated inhibition would affect the refinement of direction 273 coding and learning ability. We abolished presynaptic ChC GABA release by expressing FlpO-274 dependent TeTxLC (AAV9-CAG-dfrt-TeTxLC-HA-WPRE) in ChC-Flp mice, and performed two-275 photon calcium imaging in M2 neurons across sessions (Fig. 7a-c). ChC-TeTxLC mice showed 276 a deficit in learning the task, indicating the necessary role of axo-axonic inhibition for learning 277 goal-directed motor control (Fig. 7e-l). Given the vast difference in the numbers of PV-INs and 278 ChCs 37, it is possible that the suppression of a similar number of PV-INs has similar effects to 279 the effects exerted by the selective suppression of ChCs. To test this possibility, we abolished 280 the inhibition presynaptic GABA release of a fraction of PV-INs that corresponds approximately 281 to the percentage of ChCs in the premotor network (Extended Data Fig. 6a-c). The sparse, 282 sequential activity was observed in sparse PV-TeTxLC mice similar to PV control (Extended 283 Data Fig. 6d). However, in contrast to ChC-TeTxLC mice, the sparse PV-TeTxLC mice showed 284 normal improvement of learned performance (Extended Data Fig. 6e, f). 285 To determine the specific role of ChCs in suppressing irrelevant activity, we analyzed the 286 probabilistic distributions of neural tuning to MD as a function of learning. Compared to the 287 decrease in activity responding to non-PDs seen with learning, ChC-TeTxLC mice did not show 288 a reduced likelihood of non-PD activity over training (Fig. 7m). While the estimated probability of 289 the cell being active for non-PD movement (distance from PD > 90 degree) decreased in the 290 ChC control mice with learning, such reduction was not observed in ChC-TeTxLC mice (Fig. 291 7n). When the MD was opposite to the cell's PD, the probability of the cell being active 292 significantly decreased in the ChC-control group, but not in the ChC-TeTxLC group (Fig. 7o). 293 Consistently, we found that the decreases in pairwise correlation of neural responses with 294 learning were specific to ChC control but not ChC-TeTxLC mice (Fig. 7p). Additionally, posterior 295 probability density functions of MD were flattened over sessions in the ChC-TeTxLC group, 296 indicating impaired encoding of movement direction due to the abolition of ChC-mediated 297 inhibition (Fig. 7q). Given that intact ChC inhibition mediated the suppression of incorrectly 298 tuned responses with learning, these results collectively suggest a necessary role of ChCs in 299 refining distributed neural codes for active locomotion control. 300
301 Heterogeneous axo-axonic synaptic plasticity underlies organized motor control. 302 Our imaging data raised the possibility that ChC inhibitory synaptic strength may not be 303 uniformly altered by learning. To understand the cellular evidence in support of this claim, we 304 examined the structural rearrangement of axo-axonic synapses as proxies for the synaptic 305 strength changes in target neurons. We developed an automated detection algorithm to discern 306 the individual structures of ChC innervation on AISs of target PyNs, by using volumetric images 307 of M2 (Extended Data Fig. 7, See Methods). A large number of inhibitory presynaptic and 308 postsynaptic ChC-AIS structures, ChC axonal boutons, and gephyrin signals (GABAergic 309 inhibitory synapse scaffolding protein) along the AISs were systematically analyzed in both the 310 experimental group (n = 1634 AISs in 5 mice) and control group with ad libitum water (n = 3116 311 AISs in 6 mice) (Fig. 8a-d). We estimated structural synaptic strength by measuring presynaptic 312 structural efficacy (Pre-SSE) as a presynaptic feature and postsynaptic structural efficacy (Post-313 SSE) as a postsynaptic feature based on ChC-AIS contacts and the corresponding gephyrin 314 intensity, respectively (Extended Data Fig. 8a). The Pre- and Post-SSE distributions showed 315 intrinsic heterogeneity in both control and experimental mice, indicating uneven inhibitory 316 weights for connections between ChCs and M2 neurons (Fig. 8d-h). These imaging results are 317 consistent with early Golgi staining and recent electron microscopy data that show non-random 318 distribution of ChC axonal terminations 18,38. The strong correlation between Pre- and Post-SSE 319 showed the balance of presynaptic and postsynaptic strengths on AIS (Fig. 8i). 320 A subset of ChCs in the prelimbic cortex was reported to selectively control PyNs 321 located more superficially (< 50 μm from L1/2 border) for their specific projection to the 322 basolateral amygdala 31. We tested whether the heterogeneity among axo-axonic synapses 323 depends on the cortical depth of AIS location. The overall synaptic strengths were not different 324 by the location of AISs in L2/3 of control mice and experimental mice (0 – 250 μm from L1/2 325 border, dotted and solid lines in Fig. 8j). However, we found that high and low portions of SSE 326 distribution increased in the experimental group, suggesting that the increased heterogeneity in 327 ChC-PyN connections with learning is not solely based on the cortical depth of AIS location 328 (Fig. 8f, h). 329
To decipher how learning reorganizes axo-axonic inhibition on AISs, the cumulative 330 density functions (CDFs) of SSEs in the experimental group of mice were compared to the 331 control group (Fig. 8k, l). If a subset of neurons is more tightly controlled by ChCs with learning 332 (reflecting a sparse and determinant inhibitory control), we expect to see an increased 333 percentage of AISs largely covered or scarcely covered by ChC boutons, respectively. Indeed, 334 we observed an increased portion of both weak and strong ends in the distributions of pre and 335 post-SSEs in the trained mice. 349 Discussion 350 Given the diversity of interneuron types and their specific connectivity in neural circuits, it has 351 been a longstanding belief that the impact of inhibition on neural computation depends on a 352 combination of interneuron cell-types and their connectivity patterns 30,39–41. Genetically-defined 353 interneuron groups such as PV, SOM, and VIP, and their connectivity motifs have profoundly 354 advanced our understanding of cortical computation and psychiatric disorders. Different 355 interneuron subtypes display their own circuit motifs, but subtypes remain widely 356 heterogeneous. Therefore, we still do not fully understand the precise and unique roles of 357 inhibition mediated by most single interneuron subtypes. 358
Despite the discovery of ChCs over four decades ago 42 and their clinical relevance to 359 neuropsychiatric disorders such as schizophrenia characterized by GABAa receptor 360 dysregulation at AIS 43, the functional role of ChCs in cognition and behavior has been 361 enigmatic. Using a combination of chronic two-photon population imaging together with 362 analyses on the structural plasticity at axo-axonic synapses, we demonstrated a critical role of 363 the ChC in shaping the cortical coding of L2/3 M2 neurons during motor learning. ChC activity 364 was necessary for improving the precision and accuracy of directional movement control. ChCs 365 fine-tune the direction selectivity of individual premotor neurons and their collective tone. 366 Notably, global population activity was not perturbed when ChCs were blocked. The necessary 367 role of ChCs without perturbing overall network excitability implies that ChCs mediate their 368 regulatory effect by establishing a specific neuronal connectivity pattern for learning. 369 Quantification of a large number of ChC-AIS synapses uncovered revealed subsets of them 370 underwent modifications associated with learning. This analysis revealed a significant degree of 371 heterogeneity, which provides evidence of unequal inhibitory weighting among ChC-PyN 372 connections during learning. 373 Diverse interneurons have been shown to be involved in motor learning by shaping 374 neuronal population activity. Particularly, it has been shown that SOM-INs targeting the 375 dendrites and spines of PyNs in the primary motor cortex undergo plasticity during motor 376 learning and control learning-dependent sequential activation of PyNs in a manner comparable 377 to what is attributed to ChCs here 44. In addition, inhibiting SOM-INs during new learning 378 destabilized previous learning-dependent sequential activity of PyNs, suggesting the importance 379 of SOM-IN inhibition for maintaining previously learned sequential activation patterns and 380 behavioral improvement when a new motor skill task is introduced. However, in our study, we 381 observed that acute optogenetic suppression of SOM-INs did not significantly disrupt navigation 382 task performance after learning had been established (Fig. 3a, Extended Data Fig. 4). Given 383 the reduced activity of SOM-IN activity during learning and partial restoration of naive-like 384 activity by post-learning SOM-IN reactivation 45, the acute post-learning inhibition of SOM-INs is 385 less likely to dominantly regulate neural representations formed with learning. We cannot rule 386 out the possibility that SOM-INs are involved in shaping learning by dendritic-specific 387
computation through synaptic plasticity on the dendritic spines of PyNs. It is possible that the 388 suppression of irrelevant activity that is attributed to ChCs in the present study can be partly 389 mediated by SOM-INs via their recurrent connectivity 46. Subpopulations of SOM-INs increase 390 and decrease activities during motor learning in a task-specific manner 44. It is likely that diverse 391 and task-specific activity of SOM-INs may mediate the temporal shift of motor learning-induced 392 sequential activity in PyNs, which can complement organized population coding in sequence 393 during goal-directed navigation. 394 The abolishment of perisomatic inhibition in PV-TeTxTC mice excessively increased the 395 overall activities of M2 neurons, consistent with the notion that PV-INs are critical regulators of 396 cortical excitatory and inhibitory (E/I) balance 33,34. Perisomatic inhibition from PV-INs provides 397 powerful inhibitory control over the PyN population 29–32. Fast-spiking PV-Basket cells (PV-BCs) 398 are well suited for regulating the balance, gain and network oscillation of relatively broad PyN 399 populations 47,48. Balanced and delayed inhibition of fast-spiking INs with movement activity may 400 provide temporal sharpening of motor command and suppress irrelevant activities 35. 401 PV-BCs and ChCs have different dendritic arborizations and laminar locations of their 402 soma. They receive spatiotemporally distinct patterns of excitatory synaptic inputs from local 403 PyNs, long-range thalamocortical connections, and neuromodulatory inputs, and in turn form 404 different recurrent feedback excitation and inhibition patterns in a microcircuit 49,50. The distinct 405 wiring features and output properties of PV-BCs and ChCs may give their differential control 406 over the spike-timing of PyNs 51. Different cholinergic modulatory effects of synaptic inhibition 407 between ChCs and PV-BCs have been reported 52. Notably, a previous in vivo study showed 408 that ChCs significantly increase their firing rate during arousal when brain states switched from 409 slow to theta oscillations in the hippocampus and showed a low-amplitude desynchronized field 410 potential in the prelimbic cortex, while the firing rates of PV-BCs and PyNs remained unchanged 411 53. Given that arousal is often associated with cholinergic signaling, differential modulation by 412 cholinergic receptor activation between ChCs and PV-BCs may result in their distinct 413 contributions to population activity control in a state-dependent manner. A future study is 414 needed to further clarify the functional difference between ChCs and other types of BCs in 415 behavior control, which is important to specify the role of perisomatic inhibitory circuit motifs. 416
Our findings support a model that ChCs exert differential strengths of control over 417 subsets of PyNs after learning. There exists substantial variability in the magnitude of ChC input 418 to PyN AISs 54,55. This variability reflects the ability of ChCs to regulate their inhibitory strength 419 based on the characteristics of its target cell, and may have a role in shaping the functional 420 properties of PyNs. Variability in the number of axo-axonic ChC synapses correlated with 421 structural features of individual target PyNs including laminar depth of the soma, other sources 422 of perisomatic inhibition, and size of soma and AIS 18. The innervated PyNs are not distributed 423 at random, but rather show a clustered distribution in a spatially heterogeneous fashion 56, 424 supporting the existence of target selectivity and/or avoidance by ChCs on local PyNs. Two 425 factors possibly select PyNs for stronger/weaker inhibition. First, ChCs differently inhibit PyNs 426 based on the projection targets of the PyNs. Recent studies showed that a subset of L2 ChCs 427 selectively innervates PyNs projecting to the basolateral amygdala over those projecting to the 428 contralateral cortex in the prelimbic cortex 31. Second, ChCs differentially inhibit PyNs in an 429 activity-dependent manner during learning 57. In this study, we analyzed a restricted subset of 430 ChCs in the L2 and sampled neighboring PyNs in the shallow part of L2/3. Deeper L2/3 PyNs 431 may have different projecting targets. Nevertheless, our findings on learning-dependent 432 changes of axo-axonic synapses in the shallow L2/3 suggest that the difference in ChC-433 mediated inhibition is not solely resulted from the anatomical properties of target neurons. Given 434 experimental evidence for the activity-dependent structural plasticity of axo-axonic synapses 58–435 60, it is conceivable that the plasticity of axo-axonic synapses provides an activity-dependent 436 regulatory mechanism in the cell-by-cell level to fine-tune neuronal excitability across diverse 437 cells involved in different functional networks. This can be mediated through precise inhibitory 438 synaptic plasticity, which has been theoretically suggested as essential for the formation and 439 maintenance of functional cortical circuitry 61,62. Our findings suggest that the learning-440 dependent synaptic plasticity of axo-axonic synapses provides individualized inhibition to each 441 PyN, which is adjusted to precisely balance excitation and inhibition based on the relevancy of 442 its activity to the task goal. 443 Our measures of direction selectivity and population vector coding of MD may not fully 444 capture high-order representations such as state-dependent action selection. It is presumed that 445
multiple other inputs, such as cholinergic, thalamic, and other cortico-cortical inputs, innervate 446 ChCs and PyNs. Premotor mechanisms of direction selectivity coding, movement direction, and 447 inhibitory synaptic plasticity coming from different inputs remain to be studied. 448 Here we revealed a specialized inhibitory role for ChCs in experience-dependent 449 plasticity of cortical coding, which allows for flexible and robust learned behavior. Given the 450 unknown functions of a number of heterogeneous interneuron types, our results suggest that 451 such heterogeneity may have evolved to serve specific functional needs. Unraveling the 452 multitude of inhibitory effects on neural representation and signal transmission across all cell 453 types is essential for understanding how cognitive functions are internally and externally 454 governed to give rise to meaningful behavior. Precise balance and target-specific inhibitory 455 synaptic plasticity by each inhibitory cell type are thought to contribute to the formation and 456 retrieval of distributed memory, providing fundamental neural circuit architecture for learning. 457 The heterogeneity of inhibitory cell types with their diverse receptors and innervation patterns 458 offer us a glimpse into how the intricate and versatile neural coding in the cortex can be adopted 459 to generate complex and flexible behavior.
